title: Wall-Mounted Pencil, Paper, and Clip Holder

description.text:
We used to have a cup full of pencils sitting next to the telephone in the kitchen. Very handy, except that we kept bumping the cup and spilling all the pens and pencils on the floor.
The solution: this wall-mounted holder. It has two slots for screws (or you can just set it on a desk), and compartments for pens, pencils, a notepad, and paperclips.

• Print. This is sized to print in a 5" cube print volume (the size of an Up) if you rotate it 45 degrees about the Z axis.

  • Attach to the wall with two screws through the slots.

a five finger death punch headphone wrap

This is a simple iPhone 4/4s handlebar mount for your bike.
It is pretty tight but in return it does not fall of while riding.
You are still able to plug in the dock-connector, audio-jack and use the speakers and side buttons.
There is a version for 25.4mm and 31.8mm handlebars make sure you get the right one. See also the instructions.

• print with support and raft (i know, a lot of wasted material but no screws ;) )
    This settings worked for me:
    PLA
  • infill: 25%
  • Numbers of shells: 3
  • layer height: 0.25mm
  • about 3 hours
    • Mounting:
  • i used two 5mm cable ties
  • (place a piece of bike tube or grip tape or something similar to prevent the mount from rotating around the handlebar)
  • pull the cable ties tight

description.text: My nephew Sam has a birthday coming up, so I designed and made him this gear toy. This set has gears of multiple sizes and lets you stack gears together so you can make different gear ratios. For the base you can either print out the included base, or use a sheet of pegboard from the hardware store to go really big.

Print as many of the parts as you like, in whatever colors you like. Assemble. All parts print without support. The available parts are:

  • Gears: 1, 2, 3, and 4 inch diameters. Each diameter has a different design, and the gears can stack and lock together vertically.

  • Plates: 2 and 4 inch square plates serve as the base for building. Plates lock together to make larger layouts. You can also use commercial pegboard from the hardware store, but note that pegboard has holes spaced at 1" intervals instead of 1/2", so pegboard won't allow even-sized gears to mesh with odd-sized gears.

  • Pegs: 1, 2, 3, and 4 cm length pegs serve as the axles for the gears. The split end of the peg fits into the base plate, and gears stack onto the solid end

  • Spacers: Spacers are like gears without any teeth, and let you stack gears without meshing with a neighboring gear. The Spacer With Pegs locks onto the gear above so all the gears in a stack turn together; the Spacer No Pegs lets you build a stack of gears which can turn independently.

  • Crank: The crank fits on top of a gear (3" and 4" work best) to give you a handle to turn it with.
    • UPDATED 9/24: I've added simplified versions of the two plates which should slice and print significantly faster. I left the original versions in place in case you like the aesthetics of the exposed ribs.

comments.text: I was excited about using hardware store pegboard to save time on printing... unfortunately, it doesn't work well.  Some of the gears fit, but it's impossible to position so that a 1" will mate with a 3" or 4", for example.  Looks like the board from the store is 1" distance on center and these are smaller than that. Anyone know if there are multiple standards and I could maybe find the right stuff?

title: Cable box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I didn't like the mess of cables usually spread out on our couch for loading all of our mobile devices. So I built this  wooden box to put on our couch. It contains a 3 port german "Schuko" power plug and can hold the power cables, power adapters etc. for a netbook, an iPhone, a baby phone etc. On the front, there is a space for an iPhone to put in with its display visible and usable. The slot on the left side can hold a netbook and an iPad. On the top of the box you can put more devices with their power adapters dangling out the back of the box.

(Read the whole of these instructions before you start :) ) In the included OpenSCAD file, you can define the thickness ("Holzdicke") of your wood. It prints out the measurements for a wood thickness while rendering. Print those measurements for the thickness you need. Some common wood thicknesses are included below. There are more parameters in that openscad, so you can define the height, width and depth of the box. When changing those parameters, keep in mind that your hardware must fit in there. Visit your local DIY store. Choose a wood you like. The thickness of the wood must be a mm more than the tickness of your phone. Let them cut the wood for you. (Well you can just saw your wood yourself, but hey, I'm lazy :) ) More things to buy at that DIY store:
  • a 3 port power plug
  • small hinges (I used some parts that are meant to hang pictures)
  • some small wooden planks to put in front and back of that iPhone-shaped hole. I used 1cm x 0.5cm and 5cm x 0.5cm wooden planks.
  • wooden plugs and wooden screws.
  • a magnetic door lock (what is the exact name? see photos)
    • Back home, first lay out the different wooden parts to make sure you put everything in the right place. Some hints:
  • on front and the backside of the box, the wood is intentionally lower than on the sides. The idea is to give some ventilation to those power converters and also to put power cables out through the back.
  • The centre wood is less deep than the left and right sides. That way, you can put the power cable for the netbook through the back of the box. Just make sure the fronts of all those wooden parts match up.
  • the right side is 6cm longer, and continues below the bottom wood. On our couch, this holds the box in place. If you can not do that for your box, remove those 6cm from the design.
  • In the openscad file, the front flips downwards. I later opted for hinges on the side. Opening downward would mean the iPhone could fall flat on it's front glass, and we don't want that do we?
  • Drilling some ventilation holes into the side might look great if done well. I did not bother, because I had no ventilation issues.
    • Cut a hole in the bottom plate or the back plate for your power cable going to mains. Cut the iPhone-Shaped hole into the front wood (or any other size to match your phone :) ). Apply the small woods so that the back is closed, and the front holds your phone in place. Drill an extra hole to fit dock connector on the bottom of the phone. if you like, you might use Sugru to hold that thing in place, creating a docking station for your phone. I have not tried that. Now, drill holes into the positions where two woods meet to put some wooden plugs in. Put the woods together and put some screws in there. You probably need to drill holes for the wooden screws too, or the strain might break the wood. Before putting it all together, make sure your 3 plug power cable is in place. Do not fasten the front plate that way. use the hinges instead. Well, that's about it. Put all your power stuff in there. Have fun! P.S: Here are the sizes for some common wood strengths. I used 12mm, and you should not go below that. ECHO: "holzdicke = ", 12

title: LED holder 3d Printer - Delta (Kossel Rostock & Co.) LED (Superflux) holder (E3D hotend, but others might work, too.)

description.text:
I am building my 2nd printer. Now a Kossel. To see whats printed I decided to draw this tiny support to hold four superflux LED's.  I simply cut the fan wire of my hot-end cooler (12V) and inserted the LEDs. Depending on your LEDs you need different resistor(s) to limit the current. In my case I used 330Ohm in two parallel circuits (see picture). The superflux LEDs are not glued since bending the legs gave enough hold to keep the LEDs in position.  
I plan to glue the LED holder directly to the hot-end cooler fan. You might find a better place for it. To be honest, at the time of writing this article the LED holder is not attached yet.   
I included the sketchup file if you want to add holes for screws.  
Hope this lit a light also on your printer :)

author: polxuriach

description.text: This is a complete ukulele.  The tuning pegs are up to you, and can be found cheaply on ebay.

The parts fit together pretty well, it is mostly self explanatory.  I just .25" dowel rods to peg the neck to the body.  otherwise, I just glued the parts together using wood glue.  This design is made for 5mm plywood.  I purchased the tuning pegs from ebay for around $3, make sure you get the ones that go though the back (not right angle).  I also included some spacers that go around the tuning pegs in the back to provide friction and keep the pegs from unwinding.  
I needed to use some solid wire to keep the strings from pulling though the bridge.  I tied the strings to a short length of thick wire, this kept the strings from pulling though the bridge quite nicely.
UPDATE:
I tweaked the design and added more support for the neck.  Also added raster data for engraving grooves for frets.

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

This started (as many inside jokes do) with a misunderstanding. A group of friends were talking about a "six-toed house cat" someone heard "Toad Cat" and started asking what it was.  
In the past I would have probably photoshopped up a quick photo and emailed it to the group to poke fun at the unfortunate person that misheard. But we live in the future now, so I opened up MeshMixer and made the "Toad Cat" into a reality!  
I used two great models on Thingiverse to create this and it hardly took longer than the usual Google Image Search to Photoshop workflow.

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

As a new PrintrBot owner, I really liked abrumm's PrintrBot Lasercut Spool, but there's a problem in the design.  There should be an engrave layer and separate vector cut layer.  Otherwise the logo will cut into the spool.  
I revised the original in InkScape, put the logo in layer 0, and the vector cut on layer 1.  When I used the print driver to export to my Full Spectrum Laser, it just combined the layers.  So I've included a second version with no logo.  
Some modifications: when we cut, the slots are too far apart and the t-slots need to be longer for m3x16.  That's now the nologo-FIXED version.  
One more version:  We've switched to 1/8" plywood as it's simpler to cut than 1/4" with the 40w Laser.  R3 added holes for securing filament as well.  The last file is the 1/8" version, Printrbot_Spool_nologo_125_r3.svg.  
I'm going to do continue to do a little bit more work on this and optimize down to 4 bolts from 8.

Print, Assemble, Enjoy.
We used 1/8" plywood and 8x M3x16 bolts, nuts, and washers.
Pretty sure I can halve the number of bolts.

comments.text: Gotta tell you, this spool really is great.  Easy to cut on the laser.  An extra spool any time you need!

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/cCIoqOf5XWZ

This was a project to organize some study notecards. Unfortunately the project sort of got away from me and did not end up what I wanted. I wanted to upload everything anyway. Essentially there is a model of a Notecard (Picture) box with lid, and a couple different dividers. There are also a few versions of locks that hold one version of the dividers together. I purchased a $3 box from Walmart that I think was for pictures (I knowâ€¦still need to get the laser cutter so I could just make the box too :) ). I wanted to design and make dividers for the box so we could organize the notecards. Unfortunately my UP! printer does not have that big of a work envelope so I had to go another route. I created the parts in AutoDesk Inventor, so I posted the .ipt & iam files along with the .stl files. For simplicity I uploaded the files in two separate .zip files.
  • STL files loaded in â€œNote Card Box and Dividers STLs.zipâ€ file

  • Inventor files loaded in â€œNote Card Box and Dividers Inventor Files.zipâ€ file

  • Box & Box Lid: â€œNote Card Box.stlâ€ & â€œNote Card Box Top.stlâ€
  • Original Simple Divider (Quick Design): â€œDivider1 test.stlâ€
  • Split Dividers (to fit my printer): â€œDivider Small-Left.stlâ€ & â€œDivider Small-Right_MIR.stlâ€
  • Divider Locks & Supports (just trying different things to support the notecards): â€œDivider Lock - Standoff .stlâ€ & â€œDivider Lock 1.stlâ€ â€œDivider Lock 2.stlâ€

Print / Mod / Have Fun --- Just donâ€™t judge as the project did not go as planned ;)
All my prints were made on an Afinia UP! PP3DP printer.  I went through a bunch of trials and tests on this.  If you print the â€œdivider smallâ€ left and right parts, then you can use one of the three different lock parts to lock them together.

title: Snap-locking sphere container inspired by Demi-sphere

description.text: I loved the Hollow Demi-sphere http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3068 but I was a little bit disappointed when I found out that it does not snap fit and falls apart by itself. So I remodelled it in OpenSCAD and then changed the angles of the cut out cones to get a snap-closing sphere that does not fall apart by itself. The only drawback compared to the Demi-sphere is that the two parts are not identical anymore, but they are still very good for printing as they are both flat on the bottom (the larger part is also flat on the top).

Because I'm on holydays and did not bring my RepRap with me I could not test the optimal angle for the best fit. So I prerendered some angles: 5, 7 and 10 degrees that I think would work well. Just make sure you print the two corresponding parts. metasphere_7degrees_larger_part.stl and metasphere_7degrees_smaller_part.stl for example. FYI: for the illustrating screenshot I took an angle of 40 degrees to make the principle clear but I think it would have to bend way too much if you printed it like that so I prerendered only small angles that I think would work. I'll be back home in a day and printing some of these will be one of the first things I'll do when I get back but I wanted to see if the thingiverse community is even faster with printing it :) UPDATE: I printed the 7 degrees version. Results: The snapping is not snapping enough and the angles in which the two parts meet does not stabilize the parts so the sphere can be deformed too easily. I adapted the design by modifying the cones into straight cylinders deviating even more from the original shape but maintaining a flat base. I uploaded the new design and a stl files for a 15 degrees version that should snap nicely...I hope...well its only iteration 2 :) UPDATE: these versions don't work too well...the second does not have a flat base...I followed another approach and came to a nice snapping ball: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3272

This is a throttle control gear for a boat that uses a flex-cable to connect to the engine throttle. The gears give finer control over throttle than a simple lever, with multiple turns of the handle required to move the lever arm across it's full length.

Print each of the parts and assemble as shown in the line drawing. The ring gear, top plate, and bottom plate all bolt together with m4 threaded bar or pan head machine screws. The gears are bolted onto the planetary hub with locknuts. It may be necessary to apply the nuts hot to get them to seat well into the chassis and avoid catching. Washers and grease are advisable to minimize friction. The lever bar fits onto the back of the gear assembly between the M4 bar on the rim of the bottom and the lever arm. Hot application of the bolt into the linear gear arm is recommended to ensure a good fit.

description.text:
Extruder for the Ultimaker Original that allows printing with flexible filament.

  • This is a work in progress.

    • Description:

  • Removing the bowden tube and putting the extruder directly on the head.
    This is not just for fun, but to make printing of flexible filament possible (Filaflex, Ninjaflex for example but it can apply to any filaments that don't like long bowdens).

    • Still a WIP, but it is functional. Printing at 25mm/min gives good results. Faster than that makes the heavy head a bit shaky and degrades print quality. It is derived from the famous "Greg's-Wade's-Taylor's-Someone's extruder" and uses the original stepper from the Ultimaker. The whole thing is mounted on top of the moving head and does not need to disconnect the sensor or the heater. I still haven't found a place to mount the small ADC board so I leave it hanging from its wires at the moment. See it working:

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EIO-JXnnoNc

    • The files are here:

  • Also with more info, instructions etc...
    http://www.youmagine.com/designs/direct-non-bowden-extruder-for-ultimaker
    (Don't want to maintain multiple sets of files and instructions)

These files include all of the parts I designed for improving my printrbot. For a complete description of my modifications read here: http://polakiumengineering.com/?p=1905 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gZqbWyfKseI The final revision is now uploaded, all of the tolerances should be perfect for properly configured printrbots. Updates:
9/24/12 - X-stop is fixed in place, non-adjustable
10/04/12 - Motor mount now compatible with 28mm 36 Tooth GT2 Pulley
10/09/12 - Added LME12UU compatible parts. (See notes)
03/01/13 - Replaced by V2.0
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:55845

For more pictures and complete build instructions go here:
http://polakiumengineering.com/?p=1922 Notes:

  • If the alignment of the Z-stop is off, heat the arm of the motor mount with a torch/lighter/heat gun, then bend and hold the arm to its proper alignment until cooled.

  • Tolerances for the length of the LME12UU bearings are very close. Fitting the bearings may require additional finishing. One way of setting the bearings is to soften the plastic with a torch/lighter/heat gun before pressing the bearings into place.

Hey guys,   
this is my super high tec - low cost (3-4€!) - jump rope!  
Make one for you and your friends and start getting in shape for the beach - now!  
;)

List of needed material:
2x PG7 cable gland
2x 61801 ball bearings ( 12x21x5mm )
4x printed handle parts
ca. 3m plastic covered steel rope / laundry line (4-6mm outer diameter - e.g. 4mm laudry line )
1x tennis grip tape / tape / grip heat shrink for fishing rods / laces / ...
(Superglue) --- Assembly help --- 1) Print four of handle parts. I had the best results with the long flat side down and NO support. 2) Remove the nuts and washers from the back the cable glands 3) Press the cable glands into the ball bearing and secure it with glue if you like. (The PG7s have a 12,5mm thread, so it should be a press fit. M12 cable glands are too loose) 4) Insert a plastic covered steel cable between 4 and 6mm, roughly adjust its length and tighten the cable glands. 5) Use two handle parts, to create one handle. You can use lases, tape, glue or shrinking tube to hold the parts together. 6) Adjust to final length and start with you work out. Have fun

description.text: Dyes the Natural PLA to the colour you put on the sponge

1) Print all the parts
2) Place it around the 3mm Filament before the extruder (2 Parts)
3) Cut a bit of sponge (I used kitchen sponge)
4) Put some drops of Ink from a inkjet printer on the sponge (Messy...use gloves)
5) Place the inner top over the top.
6) Place the outer top with the clips on top of it
(I was thinking that the two tops should stop the sponge from drying out too much.) I think it will work well with kitchen dye too. Next I am thinking about what if I had a colour inkjet head that sprayed the colour on the filiment before the extruder.

remixed_from.title: Milwaukee M18 Lithium Tool Battery Adapter

title: M18 Milwaukee Battery Connector, Device Side / Battery Cover Remix

description.text:
This is a remix of the M18 Milwaukee Battery Connector. I remixed this as part of a shop organization project. I wanted a bit more multi-tasker on this.  
The battery connector can be used as a cover for when I throw batteries in my tool bag.  
I wanted mount capable to make a wall hanging setup which has my batteries sorted and "gives them a home".  
I have an older style Li-ion Milwaukee drill as well that was damaged via a drop and I'd like to fix it and update to be the same.  
Changes:  
I improved the slide action by increasing some tolerances.  
I reduced the overall amount of plastic whilst still maintaining strength.  
I added several "nubbs" to grab hold for tool bag retrieval. I also added several recessed holes for screws. You can use 6-32 panhead for a sloppy fit, 8-32 for a tight fit, or a wood screw with a flat head (like a deck screw) for screwing it into wood.  
The base is a little thin for a pistol mount on a drill, so I may thicken that later for robustness.
Printed on a Lulzbot AO101, 60mm/s ABS with 0.5 Nozzle, 0.4 Layer Height, 3mm brim with a 12 layer skirt.

comments.text: Hey. Nice job! I had a couple of ideas on tweaking this a little but have yet to learn how to tinker. The fit (width wise) is a little tight and the battery does not fully snap in because of the clamp walls not being long enough or no angle being put on the one side. I have an adapter that I could forward the dimension tweaks if your planning to update. It would be great if the base was 5mm thicker and you added some openings at the bottom to use up less plastic and prevent ABS warping wile printing.

I'm building an slightly modified ShapeOko and I needed a way to get the belts I am using properly tensioned. I am using HTD3M 10mm belts.

I am using HTD3M 10mm belts.
I have noticed the right alignment is crucial to get the system working properly, so there are two different models depending on where the tensioning bolt is (above or below the belt).
The design is for M4 bolts and it contains a nut trap. However, I am not needing to use any nut as the printed part can get the threading by turning the bolt and it is strong enough for the task. This way I can mount the same part on both sides of the belt without the need of creating a mirror part (please note the belt axis does not match the bolt axis).

comments.text: Hi Ktronik, Thanks for the comments and feedback.  I value and honor your opinion regarding external model links on thingiverse.  As I'm sure you know, these types of models do require a little more engineering and testing than your typical egg cup holder or figurine hence why we cant offer everything for free.  Whether Thingiverse and/or the community should allow these links is what you are expressing.  Ultimately we want to make our products notable and available to the 3D printing community so as they are aware of newly released unique 3D printed electronic gadgets that they can make at home.  Thingiverse is obviously the largest 3D printing community site online which is why we post our products here.  We hope that both Thingiverse and the community sees the benefits of being able to use their home 3D printer to create such products and that it acknowledges it as part of the growing manufacturing revolution that 3D printers are bringing across the globe.  If they don't we will happily take our models down from here and rely on 'other sites' as you mentioned.

I'm making a guitar, and I needed one of these.  
It's worth noting that the hole spacing on the Squier Stratocaster is different than the Fender Stratocaster.  
Edit: This was designed from a 1999 Squier Stratocaster, which is seemingly different from 2014 Squier Stratocasters, which follow the Fender hole spacing now.

Designed in Solidworks, based on 1999 Squier Stratocaster.  
The part can be printed or CNC'd, both files are attached.

Uses all of his parts. All I did was modified one part (the Cover) to fit into a 4040 Aluminum Extrusion for mounting. I take no credit for the work put behind it as Stefan did all the work. I just modified it slightly to work with my OneUp/TwoUp Full Redesign
I recommend downloading all the parts from his except for the back plate. That way they should be the latest version if he needs to tweak something internally. I included the version I based the back plate off of but if he tweaks his due to a reliability thing then the files may not be accurate. The Back plate just has hole spacing so in theory any changes on his end shouldn't affect this plate. Comment if they do and I'll re-download and update mine.

remixed_from.author: MSollack
remixed_from.title: Threadless Ball Screw. No More Backlash

description.text:
Closely based on MSollack's threadless ballscrew. I made these basically just to test the concept, so they are fairly big and bulky. The holding force is quite impressive and could easily be used for for many applications using linear drive These are made for:
10mm shafts
608zz bearings
8x20mm cap screws and M8 nuts for the bearings
5x20mm cap screw and M5 nut for the clamp They are available in 5, 10, and 15mm pitch a cool effect of running different pitches on a single shaft simultaneously is that you get a telescoping effect through rotational drive (check video)
http://youtu.be/wqZx3QNqSDY I'm planning on remaking these with smaller bearings and mounting blocks to make the more applicable for, say, 3D printers... more to come

comments.text: did you test repeatability?
comments.author: cieszyn

comments.text:
Yes, but not extensively and not under load. I'm pretty sure rigidity of the printed part will deteriorate fairly quickly under load and affect repeatability.
When, and if I end up using this for something practical I will probably machine it out of aluminum.
On the other hand, as a cheap alternative to ball screws... just print a new one if it starts to fail :)

author: kliment

description.text: A miniature scale Thonet chair, also known as a Bentwood chair.

Chair is printed in multiple pieces and requires assembly.  Honestly, this is not one of my well engineered pieces - assembly is a little fussy - but they are a lot easier to make than traditional model making allows.
Printed on a Replicator with skeinforge 47 and acceleration turned off.  Set "Extra Restart Distance to 0" under Dimension to print the small diameters in this design.  I do not have an operational skeinforge 50 profile that prints small diameters reliably at any speed - I'd welcome any tips if you're able to do so.

This is a very simple box for a 3x3 5mm LED light. I'm using it to illuminate the print area of a Rostock.
It features a 3x3 LED array, space for the legs and resistors, two holes for screwing it to a base and even a hole to pull in the cable.

Print. Stick in 9 LEDs of your choice. Wire them up (I have mine three strands of 3 lights each, with an appropriate resistor). Connect power. Enjoy night time printing. 
If it's still too dark, add more of them.

A collection of very small things, with a vague country picnic theme.  
Daid's D&D prop items have been scaled to match other items.  
The standing man is a modified google sketchup item.  Despite attempts to fix manually and in netfabb, this model throws tons of errors, but prints fine.

Windmill and picnic table require assembly.  All items should print file without support.
Printed on a Replicator with skeinforge 47 and acceleration turned off. Set "Extra Restart Distance to 0" under Dimension to print the small diameters in this design. I do not have an operational skeinforge 50 profile that prints small diameters reliably at any speed - I'd welcome any tips if you're able to do so.

This is derived from nopheads Mendel Pulley with captive M3 nut, but has been redrawn in openscad, and added more nuts for extra grip. This part is also part of my OverlapStrap project which is licenced under GPLv3 see: http://www.gilesbathgate.com/OverlapStrap/

If you want to render/modify this using openscad then you will need to take the version of openscad from svn >= r545 or Release >= openscad-2010.05 since there was a bug "normalizing zero-length normals" that prevented the resulting stl from being opened.

author: jamesrutter

description.text: Even smaller than the original.  Print for use in scale models, dollhouses or just to show off your printing skills.

Printed on a Replicator with skeinforge 47 and acceleration turned off. Set "Extra Restart Distance to 0" under Dimension to print the small diameters in this design. I do not have an operational skeinforge 50 profile that prints small diameters reliably at any speed - I'd welcome any tips if you're able to do so.
The assembled version has small discs on the feet to help with adhesion, but I often use a raft in addition as well.  I print these in multiples, always being careful to line them up in a column up the y axis, to keep the delicate columns out of the way of my second extruder.
I get about 50% breakage when printing the assembled version.  The "easy print" version is a little more reliable 25% breakage & quicker print time.

title: DJI Flame Wheel 330 rugged landing gear/suspension

description.text:
Landing gear that fits the DJI Flame Wheel 330 quadcopter. Something I designed for a mechanical engineering project at college. Assembly:
Requires 3 printed parts, 2 bolts, and a rubber band.
The left and right boots are sized to nest on either side of the existing landing leg of a DJI 330, like shown in the third image (the highlighted blue piece is the existing arm and leg of the DJI 330.) The boots are squeezed into place with 2 nuts and bolts of appropriate size ( I used some nylon bolts I had access to.) The hook at the top right of the claw piece is designed to retain a rubber band that loops around it and the quadcopter arm. This acts as a suspension, enabling the landing gear to flex around its axle. By adjusting how many times you loop the rubber band, you can tune suspension stiffness. This is not the most lightweight solution; I designed it mostly to be robust and actually protect the copter in hard landings. I included the inventor files so you can change the size of the bolt holes or other aspects of the design as you see fit.

Important: As noted in the comments, the files are exactly 10x smaller than they should be because of a mm to cm conversion error between programs. To fix, scale models up by exactly 10 times in your print preparation software, such as MakerWare.  
Built 8 copies on a Makerbot Replicator 2. Best results orienting them to "stand up", i.e. don't lay them flat. One whole side will look awful if you lay them down.

comments.author: Vapor

comments.text: Heard the same thing from the person who printed them for me. Try scaling up by exactly 10 times before printing and it should be exact. I believe this error was because I designed the parts using millimeter dimensions in Autodesk Inventor Pro 2015, but the dimensions are interpreted in centimeters by other programs.

author: Student_t

title: Clip for Ikea Ledberg LED strip - Ultimaker

description.text:
This is a clip to fit Ikea Ledberg led strip in the corners of an ultimaker.
This way you can see bright and clear what happens in your machine! I guess it works in Makerbots as well, and in any perpendicular corner you want! (Even leaves space for the cables running in the corners!)

• Print 2 per strip
  • Glue /screw in the Ultimaker (I used double-sided carpet tape)
  • Clip in the led strip.
    • I also enclose a "raw" version of the clip with only the part that clips into the led strip so you can re-use the design for whatever you like.
    In the zip file you get the .Igs and solidworks files.

title: Stepper fan mounts for Ultimaker (40mm fan)

description.text:
These are simple printable mounts to fit 40mm fans on the X,Y and E steppers of the Ultimaker.
I noticed my steppers became hot during long prints, so I found a bunch of 40mm fans to help the steppers keep a bit cooler. I guess being really warm reduces their lifetime.
I do not have any heatsinks, but I guess this will still help a lot.

-Print 2 XY mounts and one E mount.
-Assemble with 2 M3x16 screws directly into the printed holes. I attach the Solidworks and Igs files in a Zip If the mounts are not tight enough, just put some blue tape on the plywood where it will clip. The E mount works both above and under the motor.

description.text:
Designed by Barry Ambrose.  
A neckerchief slide with a big A engraved on the front.

Printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2 at Standard quality with default settings, no raft, and no supports. The source file is a little big, so you'll probably need to adjust the size down before printing.

There were a couple of models out there for the 10th doctors screwdriver, but I wasn't entirely on board with any of them out there, plus I really liked the way that Ellindsey did the 11th doctor's screwdriver (thing:169870) in that each part could be printed with a different color filament and could then be assembled into a prop without painting. Also I plan to wire it up with an LED and a button on the side or bottom. The files currently have a hollow center for the wiring, once I find a suitable button ill alter some piece of the screwdriver to house it and upload the new part. Also this can easily be the 9th doctor's sonic screwdriver with a color change either through printing in different colors or painting differently UPDATE I have printed it out as of now and it went great. Although painting is not necessary for this part (if you have all the colors) I painted the gray parts with some silver paint to give it a bit more of a metallic look. Also I wound up re-sizing the clear inner housing to make sure it slid easily through the screwdriver. I have uploaded the new file. All should be good to go. UPDATE2 In other news I have decided to make all the past versions of the Doctor's Sonic Screwdrivers say maybe one a week until they are completed so stay tuned :) UPDATE3 --- 3/14/17 --- Some have had issues printing the inner clear piece of the screwdriver (drw10scr-insd.stl) It appears this is mainly due to wall thickness and what your printer is tuned to be able to print, or extruding diameter. Therefore I have uploaded a version 2 of that file with a tad thicker walls to hopefully get around that issue for those that are having a problem. look for drw10scr-insd-V2

Rep 2, PLA, .2 mm layer height, 2 shell 20% fill, no rafts or supports. once all parts are printed I assembled as such:
glued lens to top of inside2.
slid the above assembly into the top and glued.
slid the bottom2 onto bottom1
glued the above assembly onto body
slid the clear inner onto the top/inner2 assembly and glued.
slid the top assembly into the body
glued the slider into the hole in the clear inner. All done!

v1.1 - last updated 4/29/14 This is a remix of Serin117's "MA5C ICWS - Assault rifle - Halo 3" found at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:169170 I cut the original model into easily printed pieces with pins so it would fit on the build plate and you don't have to mess around with perfectly aligning everything. All female pins are slightly wider/deeper than their male counterparts, so they should fit fine. The OpenSCAD library/files used to generate this can be found at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:310652 Have Fun!

v1.1 update changes:
-increased female pin margins for a better fit, if you've already printed one of the parts with pin holes, you should still be fine with a little sanding
-uploaded a standalone female pin, reccomend printing the stock first along with the pin, if it fits, continue on, otherwise you may need to update the radiusMarginin PinCutDemo2 - Halo AR.scad (v1.1 is .5 by default). All files can be found in the zip containing the library at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:310652 Some things to note:
-If you scale any of the pieces, you need to scale them all by the same factor.
-If you print with supports, you might need to clean out the female pin holes (depending on orientation), but that will probably just amount to sticking a drill in it or sanding off the male pins.
-You will probably still want to DAP/glue the pieces together, as the pins will not be completely solid, they might be prone to bending.

description.text:
Holds up to 12 AA batteries in a compact tabletop hopper. The batteries go in the top and are directed to the bottom of the hopper by 3 ramps.   
I want to make the next version automatically charge the two batteries at the bottom of the ramp and would love input and thoughts on this idea.

The entire thing can be printed without support.  
Note that BatteryHopper.skp has both sides defined as components. In order to print the model you'll need to "explode" them so they're attached to the ramp base. For some reason I couldn't get it to print it correctly without doing this.

comments.text: It would be simple to add contacts to the bottom to charge the bottom batteries. Just drill holes there where the ends of the batteries are. Make some contacts which will just brush the ends of the batteries as they roll into position. I'd use thin wire bristles from a wire brush. use wires to connect those brushes to the terminals in a battery charger. Plug in charger, and you're in business! Then you can just drop dead batteries in the top and get fresh batteries out the bottom.
comments.author: nearadyn

comments.text: That's what I was thinking. I'd also want to make sure the charger could go in either polarity, so I wouldn't have to be careful which way I put the battery into the hopper.

you could try to make a Arduino program that uses a voltage sensor to show the voltage of the battery and if the voltage reads negative then the battery would have its - port agents the + side of the sensor telling the Arduino to open the - charging relay on that side and the + one on the other. It would have to have a total of 4 relays and 2 on each side.
The only problem with this is that it would require the battery to have a bit of voltage in it

author: N2DaY

title: Marblevator "Mini", Counterclockwise Hand Cranked Base
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: If you wanted to build the Marblevator "Mini" series but hesitated because you didn't want to buy motors, connectors, power supplies, batteries, etc., and then have to solder the whole mess together, then this thing may be for you. This is a counter clockwise hand cranked base designed to work with the three Marblevator "Mini" tracks; Bowl, Seesaw and Zigzag (for a clockwise cranked version, see this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:313944). The photo is shown with the Marblevator "Mini", Zigzag track, but the video that follows shows all three tracks. Caveats: it does require finesse in building and a very steady hand in operating, but if I can do it, so can you as shown in this video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZIS4EiZXx2s. Printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" settings.

Study "Assembly.skp".  
Print all parts.  After printing "Base.stl" break off the four hold down disks at the corners and trim, file and/or sand smooth (the hold down disks help minimize warping during printing).  
Press "Knob Crank.stl" into the square hole in "Crank.stl".  A small dot of thick cyanoacrylate is a good idea to keep the knob assembly attached to the crank.  
Lubricate the holes that guide the crank shaft with white lithium grease.  
Slide the crank assembly part way into "Base.stl", then slip "Collar.stl" onto "Crank.stl".  
Lubricate "Gear Crank.stl" with white lithium grease then place it into position, the press "Crank.stl" into "Gear Crank.stl".  At this point, make sure the hand crank operates smoothly.  If it is tight, slightly enlarge the two holes that the crank shaft passes through by filing, sanding, trimming, or using a 15/64" drill bit, then re-lubricate.  
Lubricate "Gear Crown.stl" with white lithium grease then place it into position.  
Slide "Collar.stl" towards the hand crank to hold the hand crank in position.  This may require a number of adjustments until the hand crank and crown gear operate smoothly.  When you are sure of the final position of the collar, apply a small dot of thick cyanoacrylate to the outside edge to hold it in position.  
Install the track and press in the worm gear.  Break in the assembly be rotating the crank counter clockwise as viewed from the knob.  
Manual Marblevators Unite and Marblevate!

description.text: This assembly is designed to allow a MCU to get accurate angle and direction data using optical transistors. I've revised the design several times, and the current one seems to work, but I'm still waiting on the optical components I ordered to arrive. I will update when I have the finished prototype. http://youtu.be/_77B9df8ZBU UPDATE: Based on a suggestion from Corona688, I designed a 3 bit binary version as well. I haven't tested it yet, but I will update when I do.

The two halves each accept a 608ZZ bearing. The Shutter has a lip on the top side that will meet the bearing and the shaft has a matching lip that will meet the bearing on the other side. If you use all eight of the sensor positions, you can program the MCU to detect the direction of rotation since the shutter window will allow both the current and next sensor to trigger simultaneously. This will allow a clever programmer to get a positional accuracy of about 22.5 degrees depending on the print tolerances of the plastic, and the specific sensitivity of the optocouplers employed.  
This works best printed in a plastic that is opaque to the led color you are using.  
This design was a solution to the suggestion of 7thCrook in the comments of the Solenoid Motor. It will make V8 design possible, as well as others.  
UPDATE: The binary version require 2 cases, the binary shutter, and the spacer. Thread a 3mm machine screw through the hole in the top of the cases with the spacer between them.

comments.text: take a look at the V8 I made using a SENSOFOIL position sensor.
comments.author: 7thCrook

comments.text: How does it work?
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: The idea is that you put an led in each of the holes in one side, and a photodetector in each of the holes in the other side. Using a microcontroller you can determine which photodetectors are exposed by the slot oon the rotating shutter, thereby determining the position of the shaft. It's useful for any application that requires you to know with reasonable accuracy the rotational angle of a thing.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: How about three holes and three photodetector pairs?  Instead of a slot, the plate encodes binary.  You could encode all positions with five fewer pairs.
comments.author: mastericeman

comments.text:
That's a good idea. However, given the tolerances and resolution of the average 3d printer, a binary encoder would need to be much larger to provide a reliable position. It would require fewer components, but these components are pretty inexpensive (Less than $1 USD /pair.) An analog mulitplexer or a line encoder can be used to convert the input to binary so it doesn't require 8 pins on the MCU. And you don't need to use all positions unless you need that level of precision.
I might design one anyway, just to see if it would be comparable.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: Eight emitter-detector pairs just sounds like a pretty brute-force solution is all.  Creative use of nonprinted materials might solve the precision problem;  how about a round piece of black paper with holes poked in it?
comments.author: mastericeman

comments.text: I added a binary version. It's a little wider than the original, but I was able to save in total materials. Thanks for the suggestion.
comments.author: Corona688

comments.text: Looks good!  Print it in black of course.
comments.author: mastericeman

comments.text: That might just work, if you used cardstock. But it might be unreliable at high speeds. I'm working on a prototype now. We'll see how that goes

description.text: Split these out into separate OBJs so you can pop these into MakerWare and print them out in a whole bunch of different colors.

Just like the original, but 3 to 4 times faster. Generates the shape as a 2D surface and extrudes the entire surface at once for better performance. On my machine, 50x50 compiles are ~1h 30m, down from 6+ hours. Also fixes an error in the default parameters which sometimes generated non-manifold STLs.

The linear extrude takes up a lot of time. This will disable the preview in the Customizer, so use Preview mode, then switch it to Compile before finishing. You can only use the Customizer for 20x20 images. Much larger images are still too slow. This is mainly intended for people who want to download the OpenSCAD file and generate their own photo panes locally. To compile locally, set the mode variable to Compile, use the image array tool to generate the picture array (don't forget to invert colors), and change the width and height to your image size. Be aware that almost all the time will be taken up generating the preview in Compile mode; the actual render and compile step should take under a minute. Refer to the original version for more information.

description.text:
This receptacle fits the Milwaukee fuel M18 XC 4.0AH cordless tool batteries.

Power to the people!

This adapter could come in handy for other uses as well. Tested and working with the M18 Battery Packs! These batteries are from the Milwaukee Fuel M18 series cordless tools.
18V nominal, 4.0AH, 10X 18650x2.0AH in a 5S2P configuration. They are Samsung cells rated for 50A continous discharge.

title: Parametric Mousetrap Car Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Use this kit with a couple of old Linux distros, a drinking straw (or other axle), and some monofilament (fishing line) to build a mousetrap-powered car. There are 17 parameters you can tweak, but you'll probably be most interested in trapThickness and axleDiameter. VIDEO: http://youtu.be/p3262eKWIU8

The STL is rendered for a trap that's about 6.1mm thick, with an axle diameter of about 6.25mm. Change the trapThickness and axleDiameter parameters in the OpenSCAD file if you need different sizes. 
Use hot glue to fasten the wheel hubs and the pulley to the axle. Thread the fishing line from the top of the trap under the axle and then wrap it around until it's tight and the trap is set. You may want to use a bit of tape to get it started. 
WARNING: Don't use rat traps -- they can break bones.

head_diameter = 8
inner_diameter = 8

There are two printable parts here.  The first should be printed with supports.  It bolts to your shapeoko and you run your vacuum to one side of it.  The other fitting is for a hose with a 1" ID this runs to the print head of your shapeoko.  The second piece should be printable without support and it slides into the the hose on the print end side and then should be zap strapped to your print head.  this allows me to cut wood dust free.

description.text: English Capstone IPhone Case
Necklace motif from 3mm MDF. Diameter is appr. 100 mm.

I used a laser cutter to cut the pattern out of 3mm thick MDF sheet. Diameter is appr. 100 mm. It actually started as an experiment to create flexible structures which bend around several axes. But it turned into a necklace for my wife. :) Made during 'Open Design for Lasercutting' workshop led by Stuart Childs (oomlout.co.uk) at Aalto Fablab (http://fablab.aalto.fi/site/) at the amazing Open Knowledge Festival (okfestival.org)

description.text:
Current Version: 1.1
Last Update: 4/25/14 Inspired by Rich Olson's PuzzleCut library found at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35834 This OpenSCAD library cuts objects into interlocking pieces using simple user-defined pins. Included are several commented examples, including the Halo Assault Rifle remix shown above (also found here ).

Whatever you want it to. You decide where to cut, where to put pins, how long the pins are, and pin thickness.  
Have Fun!

Documentation can be found at:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1x8df_cExlgg-mq7IF08o6LpHAYtkTIilvuKnFUiZFI0/ (forget trying to do all this in markdown)

comments.text: Nice, each male/female pin cut is individual, if you just want the holes, you would just call the (Axis)FemalePinCut(), if it cuts on the wrong side you would change it to (Axis)FemalePinCut(dir=-1), and if you wanted to cut a female hole on both sides, you would call them both.
